title: Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard)

sections.title: Preface
sections.content: The objective of this standard is to explain the basis and general rulings for Sharikat al-’Aqd, (contractual partnership) which is known today as Musharakah, including the rulings for joint partnership, reputation (cred- itworthiness) partnership, vocation partnership, diminishing partnership and modern corporations. The explanation of these partnerships includes definitions, rulings applicable to each partnership and the Shari’ah lim- itations that must be taken into account by Islamic financial Institutions (Institution/Institutions). (1) The word (Institution/Institutions) is used here to refer, in short, to Islamic financial institutions including Islamic Banks.

sections.title: 2. Definitions, Classifications and Types of Sharikat al-’Aqd
3/1 General rulings of Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan
3/3 Service partnerships (professional or vocational partnerships and partnerships in skilled trades)
1. Scope of the Standard
sections.content: This standard covers all forms of traditional Fiqh-nominate partnerships that operate on the basis of Sharikat al-’Aqd (contractual partnership), except the partnerships that are explicitly excluded by this standard as indicated below. The standard also applies to all modern forms of partnerships including diminishing Musharakah. The standard does not cover ownership partnership where the parties jointly own an asset...

sections.title: 2. Definition, Classifications and Types of Sharikat al-’Aqd
2/1 Definition of Sharikat al-’Aqd
sections.content: Sharikat al-’Aqd (contractual partnership) means an agreement between two or more parties to combine their assets, labour or liabilities for the purpose of making profits.

sections.title: 2/2/1 Traditional Fiqh-nominate partnerships
sections.content: a) Sharikat al-’Inan (contractual partnership) b) Sharikat al-Wujuh or Al-Dhimam, i.e. partnership of creditworthiness or reputation (liability partnership) c) Sharikat al-A’mal (vocational partnerships and partnerships for undertaking difficult work or accepting jobs)

sections.title: 2/2/2 Modern Corporations
sections.content: a) Stock company b) Joint-liability company c) Partnership in commendum d) Company limited by shares e) Allotment (Muhassah) partnership f) Diminishing partnership (this partnership has originated from Sharikat al-’Inan)

sections.title: 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan
3/1/1/1 Offer and acceptance
sections.content: A Sharikah contract can be concluded by agreement between the parties concerned on the basis of offer and acceptance...

sections.title: 3/1/1/2 Partnership with non-Muslims or conventional banks
sections.content: It is permissible for the Institution to enter into a partnership contract with non-Muslims...

sections.title: 3/1/1/3 Syndicated financing with conventional banks
sections.content: It is permissible for the Institutions to include conventional banks as partners in a syndicated financing...

sections.title: 3/1/1/4 Amending partnership contract terms
sections.content: It is permissible for the partners to amend at any point of time the terms of a partnership contract...

sections.title: 3/1/2/1 Monetary assets as capital
sections.content: In principle, the capital of Sharikah should be contributed in the form of monetary assets...

sections.title: 3/1/2/2 Different currencies in partnership capital
sections.content: If partners have contributed their partnership capital in different currencies...

sections.title: 3/1/2/3 Determination of partner's share in capital
sections.content: The share of each partner in the capital should be determined...

sections.title: 3/1/2/4 Debts in Sharikah capital
sections.content: It is not permitted that debts (receivables) alone be used as a contribution to the Sharikah capital...

sections.title: 3/1/2/5 Current account funds
sections.content: The funds of current accounts, although they are juristically classified as loans to the Institutions...

sections.title: 3/1/3/1 Partner's rights
sections.content: In principle, each partner is entitled to act in the interest of the partnership...

sections.title: 3/1/3/2 Management restriction
sections.content: It is permissible for the partners to agree that the management of the partnership will be restricted...

sections.title: 3/1/3/3 Appointment of manager
sections.content: It is permissible for the partners to appoint a manager other than one of the partners...

sections.title: 3/1/3/4 Remuneration for partner manager
sections.content: It is not permitted, in a Sharikah contract, to specify a fixed remuneration for a partner...

sections.title: 3/1/3/5 Independent service contract
sections.content: It is permissible that one of the partners be appointed to provide services that are mentioned...

sections.title: 3/1/4/1 Trust basis for assets
sections.content: All partners in a Sharikah contract maintain the assets of the Sharikah on a trust basis...

sections.title: 3/1/4/2 Partner providing guarantees
sections.content: It is permissible for a partner in a Sharikah contract to stipulate that another partner provides...

sections.title: 3/1/4/3 Third-party guarantees
sections.content: A third party may provide a guarantee to make up a loss of capital...

sections.title: 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss)
3/1/5/1 Profit sharing provision
sections.content: The Sharikah contract should incorporate a provision specifying the manner of sharing profits...

sections.title: 3/1/5/2 Determination of profit percentages
sections.content: It is not permitted to defer the determination of the profit percentages...

sections.title: 3/1/5/3 Profit proportional to capital contribution
sections.content: In principle, the shares of profit may be in proportion to the percentage of each partner’s contribution...

sections.title: 3/1/5/4 Proportions of losses
sections.content: It is a requirement that the proportions of losses borne by partners be commensurate...

sections.title: 3/1/5/5 Allocation methods
sections.content: It is permissible for the partners to agree on the adoption of any method of allocation of profit...

sections.title: 3/1/5/6 Deducting expenses before profit allocation
sections.content: It is not permitted to start the allocation of profit between the partners unless the operating costs...

sections.title: 3/1/5/7 Preclusion from profit sharing
sections.content: It is not permitted that the conditions or modes of profit allocation include any clause...

sections.title: 3/1/5/8 Profit exceeding a ceiling
sections.content: It is permissible to agree that if the profit realised is above a certain ceiling...

sections.title: 3/1/5/9 Final profit distribution
sections.content: The profit may be finally distributed on the basis of the proceeds of selling all existing assets...

sections.title: 3/1/5/10 Expected profit
sections.content: It is not permitted that the final allocation of profit takes place based on expected profit...

sections.title: 3/1/5/11 Funds on account
sections.content: It is permissible to allocate some funds to any of the partners on account...

sections.title: 3/1/5/12 Revenue from leasing
sections.content: If the subject matter of Sharikah is assets acquired for leasing that bring in income...

sections.title: 3/1/5/13 Profit reservation
sections.content: It is permissible, based on the articles of association or a decision of the partners...

sections.title: 3/1/5/14 Charitable donation
sections.content: It is permissible to agree on setting aside a proportion of profit for non-partners as a charitable donation.

sections.title: 3/1/6/1 Termination rights
sections.content: Each partner is entitled to terminate the Sharikah after giving due notice...

sections.title: 3/1/6/2 Binding purchase promise
sections.content: It is permissible for a partner to issue a binding promise to buy...

sections.title: 3/1/6/3 Sharikah end
sections.content: A Sharikah venture comes to an end at the expiry date or before the expiry date...

sections.title: 3/2/1 Definition and obligations
sections.content: A partnership in creditworthiness (partnership of liability) is a bilateral agreement between two or more parties to buy assets on credit based on reputation for profit. Partners agree on profit and liability sharing ratios.

sections.title: 3/2/2 Capital and liability
sections.content: The partnership in creditworthiness has no monetary capital. The subject is an obligation or liability contingent on creditworthiness. Partners agree on liability ratios for debts.

sections.title: 3/2/3 Profit and loss distribution
sections.content: Profit is distributed as agreed. Loss is borne by partners according to the liability ratio. Lump sum profit provision for a partner is not permitted.

sections.title: 3/3/1 Definition and profit sharing
sections.content: A service partnership is an agreement to provide services or manufacture goods with profit sharing based on an agreed ratio.

sections.title: 3/3/2 Capital and service distribution
sections.content: Service partnerships have no monetary capital. Partners may distribute different services among themselves to achieve the partnership's purpose.

sections.title: 3/3/3 Profit and lump sum restrictions
sections.content: Profit is distributed according to agreed ratios. Contracts should not specify lump sum payments to particular partners.

sections.title: 3/3/4 Capital goods
sections.content: If capital goods are required, partners may contribute funds or provide them directly. Fees for providing capital goods can be charged as expenses.

sections.title: 4/1/1 Definition
sections.content: A stock company is a company with capital partitioned into tradable shares, with limited shareholder liability. It has a juristic personality through incorporation by law.

sections.title: 4/1/2/1 Contract binding and share transfer
sections.content: The stock company contract is binding for the specified duration. Shareholders cannot unilaterally dissolve but can sell shares.

sections.title: 4/1/2/2 Share value adjustments
sections.content: Permitted to add a percentage to share value for issuing expenses, appropriately estimated.

sections.title: 4/1/2/3 New share issuance
sections.content: Permissible to issue new shares at fair value, premium, or discount, based on asset valuation.

sections.title: 4/1/2/4 Underwriting shares
sections.content: Shareholder can underwrite shares without consideration, except for services like feasibility studies or marketing.

sections.title: 4/1/2/5 Instalment payments
sections.content: Payment for shares can be in instalments, forming part of the capital, provided all shares and liability are covered.

sections.title: 4/1/2/6 Interest-based loans
sections.content: Buying shares with interest-based loans is not permissible.

sections.title: 4/1/2/7 Selling shares not owned
sections.content: Selling shares not owned is impermissible, even with broker promises.

sections.title: 4/1/2/8 Trading regulations
sections.content: Authorities can organize share trading through licensed brokers.

sections.title: 4/1/2/9 Limited liability disclosure
sections.content: Publish the company's liability limitation to inform customers.

sections.title: 4/1/2/10 Share sale regulations
sections.content: Share sales must follow company regulations not conflicting with Shari'ah.

sections.title: 4/1/2/11 Mortgaging shares
sections.content: Permissibility of mortgaging company shares subject to rules.

sections.title: 4/1/2/12 Nominative shares
sections.content: Permissible to issue 'to the order of' shares.

sections.title: 4/1/2/13 Bearer shares
sections.content: Permissible to issue bearer shares with rights vesting in the certificate holder.

sections.title: 4/1/2/14 Preference shares
sections.content: Issuing preference shares with special financial characteristics is not permitted.

sections.title: 4/1/2/15 Tamattu' (enjoyment) shares
sections.content: Issuing Tamattu' shares, which partake in profit but lack voting rights, is not permitted.

sections.title: 4/2/1 Definition
sections.content: A joint-liability company is a personal partnership publicly declared with joint liability of partners.

sections.title: 4/2/2/1 Creditor rights
sections.content: Creditors can claim from any partner for company obligations.

sections.title: 4/2/2/2 Partner withdrawal
sections.content: Partners may withdraw if no company duration is set, with notification, and without harm.

sections.title: 4/2/2/3 Substitution restriction
sections.content: Partners cannot bring substitutes without agreement.

sections.title: 4/3/1 Definition
sections.content: Partnership in commendum involves managing and sleeping partners, with limited liability for sleeping partners.

sections.title: 4/3/2/1 Profit and loss allocation
sections.content: Profit distributed by lots; losses shared by partners based on capital ratio.

sections.title: 4/3/2/2 Profit restriction
sections.content: Sleeping partner cannot receive profit based on capital percentage or lump sum.

sections.title: 4/4/1 Definition
sections.content: A company limited by shares is a personal partnership with managing and sleeping partners, with liability based on shareholding.

sections.title: 4/4/2/1 Liability and management
sections.content: Managing partners have joint liability; sleeping partners' liability limited to shares.

sections.title: 4/4/2/2 Sleeping partner restrictions
sections.content: Sleeping partners cannot manage; their involvement limited to shareholding.

sections.title: 4/4/2/3 Management delegation
sections.content: Company management may be delegated to a managing partner or third party.

sections.title: 4/4/2/4 Profit and loss distribution
sections.content: Profit distributed by participation ratio; losses borne by partners based on shares.

sections.title: 4/4/2/5 Sleeping partner profit restriction
sections.content: Sleeping partner cannot receive profit based on capital percentage or lump sum.

sections.title: 4/5/1 Definition
sections.content: An allotment partnership belongs to the personal form of company, without a juristic personality.

sections.title: 4/5/2/1 Rulings alignment
sections.content: Muhassah companies follow 'Inan partnership rulings.

sections.title: 4/5/2/2 Personal liability
sections.content: Partners are personally liable for company liabilities.

sections.title: 4/5/2/3 Non-binding contract
sections.content: Partnership contract is not binding unless agreed otherwise.

sections.title: 4/5/2/4 Withdrawal conditions
sections.content: A partner can withdraw upon notification without causing harm.

sections.title: 5/1 Definition
sections.content: Diminishing Musharakah is a partnership where one partner promises to buy the equity share of the other.

sections.title: 4/5/1/2 Sharikat al-Muhassah
sections.content: Sharikat al-Muhassah has no juristic personality because people other than the partners do not know about it. This partnership does not have any separate financial liability as an entity.

sections.title: 4/5/2 Shari’ah rulings relating to Muhassah Company
4/5/2/1 Rulings for Muhassah and 'Inan partnership
sections.content: The rulings for and basis of a Muhassah company do not differ from those for an ’Inan partnership.

sections.title: 4/5/2/2 Personal liability of partners
sections.content: The liability of partners is personal and, as such, they are liable for the liabilities of the company from their personal assets.

sections.title: 4/5/2/3 Contract binding nature
sections.content: The contract of a Muhassah partnership is not binding. However, if the parties agree to make it binding for a particular period of time, then they shall be bound by such an agreement.

sections.title: 4/5/2/4 Termination of partnership
sections.content: A partner in Sharikat al-Muhassah is entitled to terminate his partnership on condition that (I) he notifies other partners of his intention to withdraw and (II) the unilateral withdrawal from partnership would not cause damage to other partners or clients of the company.

sections.title: 5/1 Definition of Diminishing Musharakah
sections.content: Diminishing Musharakah is a form of partnership in which one of the partners promises to buy the equity share of the other partner gradually until the title to the equity is completely transferred to him.

sections.title: 5/2 General rules for Diminishing Musharakah
sections.content: The general rules for partnerships must be applied to a diminishing partnership, especially the rules for Sharikat al-’Inan.

sections.title: 5/3 Cost of insurance or maintenance
sections.content: It is not permitted to stipulate that one partner should bear all the cost of insurance or maintenance on the ground that he will eventually own the subject matter of the partnership.

sections.title: 5/4 Capital contribution
sections.content: Each partner should contribute part of the capital. The contribution may be in the form of cash or tangible assets that can be translated into a monetary value.

sections.title: 5/5 Profit sharing
sections.content: The ratio of profit or income of the partnership that each partner (the Institution and customer) is entitled to should be clearly determined.

sections.title: 5/6 Lump sum from profits
sections.content: It is not permitted to stipulate that one partner has a right to receive a lump sum out of the profits.

sections.title: 5/7 Equity share acquisition promise
sections.content: It is permissible for one of the partners to give a binding promise that entitles the other partner to acquire his equity share gradually, but not at their original or face value.

sections.title: 5/8 Acquisition arrangement
sections.content: The partners may arrange for the acquisition of the equity share of the Institution in a manner that serves the interests of both parties.

sections.title: 5/9 Renting or leasing partner's share
sections.content: It is permissible for either of the partners to rent or to lease the share of the other partner for a specified amount and duration.

sections.title: 6 Date of Issuance of the Standard
sections.content: This Standard was issued on 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 16 May 2002 A.D.

sections.title: Adoption of the Standard
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standard on Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations was adopted by the Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (8) held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11-16 May 2002 A.D.

sections.title: 1/1_permissibility_of_partnership
sections.content: The Fuqaha have classified partnerships into four categories, namely Sharikat al-’Inan (contractual partnership), Sharikat al-Abdan (skilled trade partnership), Sharikat al-Mufawadah (agency-like partnership) and Sharikat al-Wujuh (creditworthiness or reputation partnership). The most important of all is Sharikat al- ’Inan (contractual partnership). The permissibility of this form of partnership is established by the Qur`an, the Sunnah and practical consensus of the Fuqaha...

sections.title: 1/2_conclusion_of_sharikah_contract
sections.content: It is permitted to conclude a partnership contract with non-Muslims or conventional banks for carrying out permissible operations in association with necessary guarantees that they will observe Shari’ah precepts and principles...

sections.title: 1/3_capital_of_sharikah
sections.content: The basis for the permissibility that Sharikah capital may be contributed in the form of tangible assets other than cash, after valuation...

sections.title: 1/4_managing_a_partnership
sections.content: The basis for the right of each partner to participate in the management of the partnership is that partnership is based on elements of agency and trust...

sections.title: 1/5_guarantees_in_partnership
sections.content: The basis of the requirement that a partner is not liable except in cases of misconduct or negligence...

sections.title: 1/6_outcome_of_partnership_investment
sections.content: The basis for the impermissibility of an agreement to determine the profit share on the basis of a lump sum or a percentage of the capital...

sections.title: 1/7_termination_of_partnership
sections.content: The basis for the rule that termination of partnership will not affect obligations and actions that took place before it...

sections.title: 1/8_modern_corporations
sections.content: The permissibility of modern corporations is dependent on the principle of Shari’ah that human transactions are, in principle, permissible...

sections.title: 1/9_stock_companies
sections.content: The basis for the permissibility of underwriting issues of shares without taking consideration is that this is an undertaking that does not involve an impermissible act...

sections.title: 2/1_joint_liability_company
sections.content: The basis for the permissibility of the undertaking of partners in a joint liability company to be jointly responsible...

sections.title: 2/2_partnership_in_commendum
sections.content: The basis for the impermissibility of sleeping partners of partnership in commendum or company limited by shares being entitled to interfere in the management...

sections.title: 3_allotment_particular_partnership
sections.content: The basis for the permissibility of unilateral termination of participation in this kind of partnership by any of the partners...

sections.title: 4_diminishing_partnership
sections.content: The basis for saying that all the general rules for partnerships, especially the rules for ’Inan partnership, are applicable to diminishing partnerships...

sections.title: Contract Partnership (Sharikat al-’Aqd)
sections.content: Contract partnership is an agreement between two or more parties to combine their assets or to merge their services or obligations and liabilities with the aim of making profit.

sections.title: Partnership of Ownership (Sharikat al-Milk)
sections.content: Partnership of ownership (Sharikat al-Milk) is the combination of the assets of two or more persons in a manner that creates a state of sharing the realised profit or income or benefiting from an increase in the value of the partnership assets. This combination of assets for making profit necessitates bearing losses, if any. The ownership partnership is created by events beyond the partners’ control such as the inheritance rights of heirs in the legacy of a deceased person. This partnership is also created by the wish of the partners such as when two or more parties acquire common shares in a particular asset.

sections.title: Mufawadah Partnership
sections.content: Mufawadah partnership is any partnership in which the parties are equal in all respects, such as funds contributed by them, their right to act and their liability, from the commencement of the partnership to the date of its termination.

sections.title: Sharecropping Partnership (Muzara’ah)
sections.content: Sharecropping is partnership in crops in which one party presents land to another for cultivation and maintenance in consideration for a common defined share in the crop.

sections.title: Irrigating Partnership (Musaqat)
sections.content: Irrigating partnership is a partnership that depends on one party presenting designated plants/trees that produce edible fruits to another in order to work on their irrigation in consideration for a common defined share in the fruits.

sections.title: Agricultural Partnership (Mugharasah)
sections.content: Agricultural partnership is a partnership in which one party presents a treeless piece of land to another to plant trees on it on the condition that they share the trees and fruits in accordance with a defined percentage.

sections.title: Distribution of Proceeds and Profits
sections.content: Distribution of proceeds and profits is a process of termination an undivided ownership in the company by the final distribution of the assets whereby rights of each partner are defined and common shares are partitioned into identified sets for each partner. This is why distribution is defined as identification of undefined shares or proceeds of a particular person.

sections.title: Preface
sections.content: The aim of this standard is to explain the Shari’ah rulings for restricted and unrestricted Mudarabah, whether the Islamic financial Institution is acting in the capacity of a Mudarib (entrepreneur) or in the capacity of an investor.

sections.title: 1. Scope of the Standard
sections.content: This standard covers Mudarabah contracts between the Institution and other entities or individuals. It also covers joint investment accounts and special purpose investment accounts based on Mudarabah. It does not cover Sukuk of Mudarabah or other partnership contracts.

sections.title: 2. Definition of Mudarabah
sections.content: Mudarabah is a partnership in profit where one party provides capital (Rab al-Mal) and the other party provides labour (Mudarib).

sections.title: 3/1 Permissibility
sections.content: It is permissible to conclude Mudarabah financing contracts for a specific sum and duration based on a general framework or memorandum of understanding.

sections.title: 3/2 Memorandum Details
sections.content: The memorandum should define the contractual framework, intention of using unrestricted or restricted Mudarabah, profit ratio, and types of guarantees.

sections.title: 3/3 Integral Part of Contract
sections.content: If a Mudarabah contract is concluded based on the memorandum, it becomes an integral part unless agreed otherwise.

sections.title: 4/1 Contract Terminology
sections.content: The Mudarabah contract may use terms like Mudarabah, Qirad or Mu’amalah.

sections.title: 4/2 Legal Capacity Requirement
sections.content: Both parties must have the legal capacity to appoint agents and accept agency.

sections.title: 4/3 Binding Nature
sections.content: A Mudarabah contract is not binding, except when the Mudarib has commenced the business or if a duration is agreed.

sections.title: 4/4 Trust-Based Contract
sections.content: The Mudarib is not liable for losses unless there is misconduct, negligence, or breach of trust.

sections.title: 5/1 Unrestricted Mudarabah
sections.content: In unrestricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib has freedom to trade but must act in party's interest.

sections.title: 5/2 Restricted Mudarabah
sections.content: In restricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib's actions are limited to certain locations or types of investment.

sections.title: 6. Guarantees in a Mudarabah Contract
sections.content: Guarantees are permissible to cover misconduct, negligence, or breach of contract by the Mudarib.

sections.title: 7/1 Form of Capital
sections.content: Capital must be in cash or tangible assets, the value of which is agreed or appraised.

sections.title: 7/2 Clarity of Capital
sections.content: The capital should be clearly known, defined in terms of quality and quantity.

sections.title: 7/3 Debt as Capital
sections.content: Debts cannot be used as capital in a Mudarabah contract.

sections.title: 7/4 Control of Capital
sections.content: Capital must be put at the disposal of the Mudarib for the contract to be valid.

sections.title: 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit
8/1 Profit Distribution Mechanism
sections.content: The profit distribution mechanism must be clear and based on agreed percentages.

sections.title: 8/2 Additional Profit and Fees
sections.content: A profit share in addition to a fee is not permissible unless for activities outside Mudarabah.

sections.title: 8/3 Agreed Profit Ratios
sections.content: Parties agree on profit ratios which can be changed anytime through mutual agreement.

sections.title: 8/4 Customary Profit Distribution
sections.content: If not stipulated, customary practice may determine profit shares.

sections.title: 8/5 Stipulation of Lump Sum
sections.content: Stipulation of a lump sum for profit renders the contract void.

sections.title: 8/6 Profit Assignment Restrictions
sections.content: Profit assignment to separate capitals or periods is not permissible.

sections.title: 8/7 Condition of Capital Maintenance
sections.content: Profit cannot be claimed unless the capital is maintained intact.

sections.title: 8/8 Entitlement to Profit
sections.content: Mudarib’s entitlement to profit is realized upon recognition, subject to interim profits for capital protection.

sections.title: 8/9 Commingling of Funds
sections.content: Mudarib’s own funds mixed with Mudarabah funds affect profit distribution proportions.

sections.title: 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib
9/1 Unrestricted Duties
sections.content: Mudarib can operate freely in permissible activities and appoint others if necessary.

sections.title: 9/2 Permissible Restrictions
sections.content: Capital provider may impose location, time, or sector restrictions on Mudarib's operations.

sections.title: 9/3 Capital Provider's Stipulations
sections.content: Capital provider cannot stipulate involvement in Mudarib’s operations or restrict Mudarib’s actions unnecessarily.

sections.title: 9/4 Standard Responsibilities
sections.content: Mudarib responsible for customary asset management tasks without additional fees.

sections.title: 9/5 Pricing Restrictions
sections.content: Mudarib must trade at market prices unless benefits to Mudarabah are clear.

sections.title: 9/6 Loan and Donation Prohibition
sections.content: Loans or donations from Mudarabah funds are not permissible without consent.

sections.title: 9/7 Expense Rights
sections.content: Mudarib may receive living and traveling expenses with prior approval or as per custom.

sections.title: 10/1 Methods of Liquidation
sections.content: A Mudarabah can be liquidated through unilateral termination, mutual agreement, maturity date, exhaustion of funds, or death of the Mudarib.

sections.title: 10/2 Maturity Procedure
sections.content: Assets must be liquidated as per profits distribution protocols on maturity.

sections.title: 11. Date of Issuance of the Standard
sections.content: This Standard was issued on 4 Rabi’ I, 1424 A.H., corresponding to 16 May 2002 A.D.

sections.title: Adoption of the Standard
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standard on Mudarabah was adopted by the Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (8) held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah during the period of 28 Safar to 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11-16 May 2002 A.D.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Shari’ah Standard No. 13: Mudarabah

sections.title: Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard
5/1/1: Initial Decision
sections.content: In its meeting No. (5) held in Makkah Al-Mukarramah during the period of 8-12 Ramadan 1421 A.H., corresponding to 4-8 December 2001 A.D., the Shari’ah Board decided to give priority to the preparation of a Shari’ah Standard on Mudarabah.

sections.title: 5/1/2: Consultant Commissioning
sections.content: On Saturday 15 Dhul-Hajjah 1421 A.H., corresponding to 10 March 2001 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee recommended to the Shari’ah Board the commissioning of a Shari’ah consultant to prepare a juristic study and an exposure draft on the Shari’ah Standard for Mudarabah.

sections.title: 5/1/3: Draft Discussion and Amendments
sections.content: In its meeting held on 18 Muharram 1422 A.H., corresponding to 12 April 2001 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee discussed the exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules for Mudarabah and asked the consultant to make amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

sections.title: 5/1/4: Further Revisions
sections.content: The Committee also held a meeting on 20 Jumada II, 1422 A.H., corresponding to 8 December 2001 A.D., and made some amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

sections.title: 5/2: Presentation to Shari’ah Board
sections.content: The revised exposure draft of the Standard was presented to the Shari’ah Board in its 7th meeting held in Makkah Al-Mukarramah during the period of 9-13 Ramadan 1422 A.H., corresponding to 24-28 November 2001 A.D. The Shari’ah Board made further amendments to the exposure draft of the Standard and decided that it should be distributed to specialists and interested parties in order to obtain their comments with the objective of discussing them in a public hearing.

sections.title: 5/3: Public Hearing
sections.content: A public hearing was held in Bahrain during the period of 29-20 Dhul-Hajjah 1422 A.H., corresponding to 2-3 February 2002 A.D. The public hearing was attended by more than thirty participants representing central Institutions, Institutions, accounting firms, Shari’ah scholars, academics and others who are interested in this field.

sections.title: 5/4: Committee Discussion and Amendments
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standards Committee in its meeting held during the period of 21-22 Dhul-Hajjah 1422 A.H., corresponding to 6-7 March 2002 A.D., in the Kingdom of Bahrain discussed the comments made on the exposure draft. The Committee made the amendments which it considered necessary in light of both the discussions that had taken place in the public hearing and the written comments that had been received.

sections.title: 5/5: Final Shari’ah Board Review
sections.content: The Shari’ah Board in its 8th meeting held on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11-16 May 2002 A.D., in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah discussed the amendments made by the Shari’ah Standards Committee, and made the necessary amendments, which it deemed necessary. Some paragraphs of the standard were adopted by the unanimous vote of the members of the Shari’ah Board, while the other paragraphs were adopted by the majority vote of the members.

sections.title: 5/6: Shari’ah Standards Review Committee
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standards Review Committee reviewed the Standard in its meeting held on Rabi’ II, 1433 A.H., corresponding to March 2012 A.D., in the State of Qatar, and proposed after deliberation a set of amendments (additions, deletions, and rephrasing) as deemed necessary, and then submitted the proposed amendments to the Shari’ah Board for approval.

sections.title: 5/7: Final Approval
sections.content: In its 41st meeting held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia during the period of 27-29 Sha’ban 1436 A.H., corresponding to 14-16 June 2015 A.D., the Shari’ah Board discussed the proposed amendments submitted by the Shari’ah Standards Review Committee. After deliberation, the Shari’ah Board approved necessary amendments, and the Standard was adopted in its current amended version.

sections.title: Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard
Permissibility of Mudarabah and Its Rationale
Permissibility from Qur'an
sections.content: Mudarabah contract derives its permissibility from the Qur’an: {“Others travelling through the land, seeking of Allah’s bounty”}. This verse is interpreted to mean those who travel for the purpose of trading and seeking permissible income.

sections.title: Permissibility from Sunnah
sections.content: The Hadith of Al-’Abbas Ibn Abdul-Muttalib and others support the permissibility of Mudarabah.

sections.title: Consensus Among Scholars
sections.content: There is generally consensus among the scholars in respect to the permissibility of a Mudarabah contract.

sections.title: Rationale for Permissibility
sections.content: Money cannot increase unless associated with work. Mudarabah facilitates cooperation between those with capital and those with business expertise.

sections.title: Legal Capability and Agency
sections.content: Both parties must be legally capable to appoint, or act as, an agent since each acts as an agent of the other.

sections.title: Non-binding Nature Initially
sections.content: The Mudarabah contract is initially non-binding because the Mudarib is merely an agent.

sections.title: Binding Nature After Commencement
sections.content: Once work has commenced, the Mudarabah contract becomes binding to prevent loss to the Mudarib.

sections.title: Time Limitation
sections.content: A time limit for the Mudarabah operation is permissible as it relates to agency contracts with designated durations.

sections.title: Trustee Role of Mudarib
sections.content: The Mudarib is considered a trustee for the Mudarabah funds. The Mudarib and the owner share benefits, and the risks are borne by the funds.

sections.title: Guarantees in a Mudarabah Contract
sections.content: Guarantees are allowed in case of misconduct and negligence of the Mudarib, as they then become liable for losses.

sections.title: Capital in Tangible Assets
sections.content: The capital may be constituted by tangible assets to achieve profit.

sections.title: Known Amount
sections.content: The capital amount must be clearly known to avoid uncertainty or ambiguity.

sections.title: Debt as Capital
sections.content: A debt owed by the Mudarib cannot be contributed as it is not available for use.

sections.title: Capital Presentation
sections.content: The capital must be presented to the Mudarib to manage and achieve the Mudarabah objective.

sections.title: Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit
Profit Ratio
sections.content: The profit ratio must be known as it is the subject matter of a Mudarabah contract.

sections.title: Profit Share
sections.content: The profit share must be a percentage of profit, not a lump sum.

sections.title: Simultaneous Profit and Fee
sections.content: Impermissible to receive both profit share and fee as it precludes sharing profit.

sections.title: Changing Profit Ratio
sections.content: Agreement to change profit distribution is permissible as it does not preclude profit sharing.

sections.title: Silent Profit Ratio
sections.content: Contract is nullified if silent on profit ratio and no customary distribution practice exists.

sections.title: Duties and Powers of the Mudarib
Freedom of Action
sections.content: In an unrestricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib is allowed freedom of action to achieve profit.

sections.title: No Stipulation by Capital Provider
sections.content: The capital provider cannot stipulate a right to work with the Mudarib or interfere with Mudarabah operations.

sections.title: Use of Funds for Loans or Donations
sections.content: The Mudarib cannot make loans or donations from Mudarabah funds as it does not benefit the operation.

sections.title: Unilateral or Agreement Liquidation
sections.content: Allowed to liquidate Mudarabah unilaterally, by agreement, or at maturity date.

sections.title: Loss of Capital
sections.content: Termination permitted if capital is lost as it cannot be worked.

sections.title: Death of Mudarib
sections.content: Termination is allowed if the Mudarib dies, similar to an agency contract.

sections.title: Differences Between Mudarabah and Sharikah
sections.content: Mudarabah involves both capital and work by Mudarib, whereas Sharikah involves joint capital contribution.
